_decoded_content.name: The Platteville Button - adaptive switch
_decoded_content.description:
The “Platteville Button” design was developed by Nick Shaw. It came about as part of an optional assignment of the Engineering Physics Systems course at the University of Wisconsin Platteville, taught by Dr. Harold T. Evensen; the course serves as an introduction to the Engineering Physics Department and coursework, while teaching PLC and microcontroller programming. 
The “Platteville Button” is designed to connect to electronic toys that are adapted with a 3.5mm female mono speaker jack, for users with special needs. The point of the “Platteville Button” project was to create a cost-effective, simple, and widely usable button that was able to be manufactured by families or organizations to serve as an alternative to the commercial buttons. The button can also be created in-house by UW-Platteville students or faculty and distributed with adapted "Toy Hack" toys as needed. The exact cost of the Platteville Button depends on the exact materials used and the quantity being produced, but the average cost to create a few is generally well under $10 per unit.
It is important to note that this button utilizes a home-made “circuit board insert” to assist in the electrical connections, which requires a CNC Mill or Router and some knowledge in CAD and CAM to manufacture. A .step file of the circuit board insert has been included in the files, though given the thousands of possible machines they could be manufactured on and variety of likely setups, I have not included the particular code I used when cutting mine out to avoid confusion. 
The documents include (1) a description of the fabrication process [.PDF]; (2) files for 3D printing (including three button sizes) [.STL]; (3) file for the circuit board insert [.STEP].
See the Assembly Instructions for notes and pointers on making the board insert, including a more in-depth explanation of how the button itself functions.

_decoded_content.details:
Summary

The “Platteville Button” design was developed by Nick Shaw. It came about as part of an optional assignment of the Engineering Physics Systems course at the University of Wisconsin Platteville, taught by Dr. Harold T. Evensen; the course serves as an introduction to the Engineering Physics Department and coursework, while teaching PLC and microcontroller programming.
The “Platteville Button” is designed to connect to electronic toys that are adapted with a 3.5mm female mono speaker jack, for users with special needs. The point of the “Platteville Button” project was to create a cost-effective, simple, and widely usable button that was able to be manufactured by families or organizations to serve as an alternative to the commercial buttons. The button can also be created in-house by UW-Platteville students or faculty and distributed with adapted "Toy Hack" toys as needed. The exact cost of the Platteville Button depends on the exact materials used and the quantity being produced, but the average cost to create a few is generally well under $10 per unit.
It is important to note that this button utilizes a home-made “circuit board insert” to assist in the electrical connections, which requires a CNC Mill or Router and some knowledge in CAD and CAM to manufacture. A .step file of the circuit board insert has been included in the files, though given the thousands of possible machines they could be manufactured on and variety of likely setups, I have not included the particular code I used when cutting mine out to avoid confusion.
The documents include (1) a description of the fabrication process [.PDF]; (2) files for 3D printing (including three button sizes) [.STL]; (3) file for the circuit board insert [.STEP].
See the Assembly Instructions for notes and pointers on making the board insert, including a more in-depth explanation of how the button itself functions.

Photos & Required Materials

                <p class="detail-caption"><strong>The completed button.</strong></p>            <p class="detail-image"><img src="https://cdn.thingiverse.com/assets/54/9b/6b/66/ba/circuit_board_insert.png"></p>                <p class="detail-caption"><strong>The circuit board insert. This significantly reduces the wiring and soldering required, while increasing the button's sensitivity.</strong></p>            <p class="detail-title"><strong>Required Materials</strong></p>            <div><p>The following materials and equipment are required to create the “Platteville Button”.<br>•   A 3D Printer with filament (Approximately 55 grams per button at the settings below)<br>o   PLA works well, though other filaments can be used as desired.<br>•   A thin putty knife/scraper<br>o   Used during the print cleanup process.<br>•   Sandpaper<br>•   Single-sided copper-clad PCB board<br>o   2x3in and 4x3in work well. These can be purchased from Amazon.com or other retailers. The “standard” PCB thickness is 0.063inches or 1.57mm.<br>•   Male mono 3.5mm headphone jacks (and wire if necessary) (1 per button)<br>o   You can either purchase the connectors and solder wires to them yourself or purchase pre-made leads with wires on one side. It is also possible to purchase double-sided cords (often labeled “aux cords”) and cut them in half to make two leads. MAKE SURE TO ONLY USE MONO JACKS. Stereo jacks can operate in unintended ways.<br>o    If you are supplying your own wire, use 20 or 22 gauge stranded wire.<br>•   Wire Strippers<br>o    Necessary for working with the wires & headphone jacks.<br>•   A soldering iron and solder<br>o    Most soldering tips will work; see soldering instructions in Assembly Instructions for more details on how to solder the limit switches to the circuit board inserts.<br>•   Limit Switches (3 per button)<br>o    I utilized Omron SS-3GP limit switches for my buttons; the circuit board inserts are designed to fit their "legs."<br>o    Ensure that the limit switches you use are for through-holes and feature prongs where the longest edge of them is parallel to the longest edge of the switch body.<br>o    Depending on the profile of the limit switch you utilize, you may require the use of tape as “shim” on the pressing cylinders.<br>•   Electrical or Masking Tape<br>o    Used as spacing between the upper half of the shell and the buttons on the limit switches.<br>•   Hot Glue<br>o    Used to seal the hole in the bottom half print where the wire exits.<br>•   A CNC mill or router<br>o    Used to create the circuit board inserts. See the notes listed under Circuit Board Insert Manufacturing for more information.<br>o    1/16th inch flat or ball nose endmill</p><p>Recommended Materials:<br>•   Super Glue<br>o    Used to hold the switch to the circuit board insert, while soldering.<br>•   Multimeter<br>o    Used to check the electrical connections.</p></div>

data.content:
The “Platteville Button” design was developed by Nick Shaw. It came about as part of an optional assignment of the Engineering Physics Systems course at the University of Wisconsin Platteville, taught by Dr. Harold T. Evensen; the course serves as an introduction to the Engineering Physics Department and coursework, while teaching PLC and microcontroller programming.
The “Platteville Button” is designed to connect to electronic toys that are adapted with a 3.5mm female mono speaker jack, for users with special needs. The point of the “Platteville Button” project was to create a cost-effective, simple, and widely usable button that was able to be manufactured by families or organizations to serve as an alternative to the commercial buttons. The button can also be created in-house by UW-Platteville students or faculty and distributed with adapted "Toy Hack" toys as needed. The exact cost of the Platteville Button depends on the exact materials used and the quantity being produced, but the average cost to create a few is generally well under $10 per unit.
It is important to note that this button utilizes a home-made “circuit board insert” to assist in the electrical connections, which requires a CNC Mill or Router and some knowledge in CAD and CAM to manufacture. A .step file of the circuit board insert has been included in the files, though given the thousands of possible machines they could be manufactured on and variety of likely setups, I have not included the particular code I used when cutting mine out to avoid confusion.
The documents include (1) a description of the fabrication process [.PDF]; (2) files for 3D printing (including three button sizes) [.STL]; (3) file for the circuit board insert [.STEP].
See the Assembly Instructions for notes and pointers on making the board insert, including a more in-depth explanation of how the button itself functions.

data.caption: The circuit board insert. This significantly reduces the wiring and soldering required, while increasing the button's sensitivity.

data.title: Required Materials
data.content:
The following materials and equipment are required to create the “Platteville Button”.
• A 3D Printer with filament (Approximately 55 grams per button at the settings below)
o PLA works well, though other filaments can be used as desired.
• A thin putty knife/scraper
o Used during the print cleanup process.
• Sandpaper
• Single-sided copper-clad PCB board
o 2x3in and 4x3in work well. These can be purchased from Amazon.com or other retailers. The “standard” PCB thickness is 0.063inches or 1.57mm.
• Male mono 3.5mm headphone jacks (and wire if necessary) (1 per button)
o You can either purchase the connectors and solder wires to them yourself or purchase pre-made leads with wires on one side. It is also possible to purchase double-sided cords (often labeled “aux cords”) and cut them in half to make two leads. MAKE SURE TO ONLY USE MONO JACKS. Stereo jacks can operate in unintended ways.
o If you are supplying your own wire, use 20 or 22 gauge stranded wire.
• Wire Strippers
o Necessary for working with the wires & headphone jacks.
• A soldering iron and solder
o Most soldering tips will work; see soldering instructions in Assembly Instructions for more details on how to solder the limit switches to the circuit board inserts.
• Limit Switches (3 per button)
o I utilized Omron SS-3GP limit switches for my buttons; the circuit board inserts are designed to fit their "legs."
o Ensure that the limit switches you use are for through-holes and feature prongs where the longest edge of them is parallel to the longest edge of the switch body.
o Depending on the profile of the limit switch you utilize, you may require the use of tape as “shim” on the pressing cylinders.
• Electrical or Masking Tape
o Used as spacing between the upper half of the shell and the buttons on the limit switches.
• Hot Glue
o Used to seal the hole in the bottom half print where the wire exits.
• A CNC mill or router
o Used to create the circuit board inserts. See the notes listed under Circuit Board Insert Manufacturing for more information.
o 1/16th inch flat or ball nose endmill

Recommended Materials:
• Super Glue
o Used to hold the switch to the circuit board insert, while soldering.
• Multimeter
o Used to check the electrical connections.
